articles.headline: Insider Inquiry Inching Closer to a Billionaire
articles.snippet: Prosecutors charged a former employee of SAC Capital Advisors with insider trading in a case that directly involves the hedge fund’s powerful founder, Steven A. Cohen.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors charged a former employee of SAC Capital Advisors with insider trading in a case that directly involves the hedge fund’s powerful founder, Steven A. Cohen.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last half-decade, as federal authorities secured dozens of insider trading convictions against hedge fund traders, they have tried doggedly to build a case against one of Wall Street’s most influential players: the billionaire stock picker Steven A. Cohen.

articles.headline: Elmo Puppeteer Resigns After Fresh Allegation
articles.snippet: Kevin Clash, the puppeteer behind the Elmo character resigned.
articles.abstract: Kevin Clash, the puppeteer behind the Elmo character resigned.
articles.lead_paragraph: 5:11 p.m. | Updated  Kevin Clash, the longtime voice and puppeteer behind “Sesame Street’s” Elmo character, resigned on Tuesday after a new allegation was made that he had underage sexual relationships.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Jensen and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Politics Complicates the Math in Ending Tax Breaks for Rich
articles.snippet: Experts say that raising revenue without increasing rates would involve wiping out nearly every deduction, credit and preferential rate that affluent households claim.
articles.abstract: Experts say that raising revenue without increasing rates would involve wiping out nearly every deduction, credit and preferential rate that affluent households claim.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Whether to raise revenue through increasing tax rates or cutting loopholes has become a central sticking point in the negotiations on a major debt deal.

articles.headline: Missile’s Firing, Bomb Blasts and Sirens Shatter Gaza Calm
articles.snippet: People waiting for foreign ministers to arrive at a Gaza hospital were startled by a nearby rocket launching, then by a deluge of wounded in the firefight with Israel.
articles.abstract: People waiting for foreign ministers to arrive at a Gaza hospital were startled by a nearby rocket launching, then by a deluge of wounded in the firefight with Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Hundreds of people were packed into Al Shifa Hospital plaza, eagerly awaiting the arrival of an Arab League delegation of foreign ministers. A platform with news cameras had been set up, along with a movie screen flashing images of patients wounded during days of airstrikes. A boy wandered around with a kettle and a thermos, hawking coffee and tea, 25 cents per plastic cup.

articles.headline: Airlines’ On-Time Performance Rises
articles.snippet: Airlines have found ways to overcome the challenges of departing on schedule just in time for the busy holiday travel season.
articles.abstract: Airlines have found ways to overcome the challenges of departing on schedule just in time for the busy holiday travel season.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Next time you dawdle at the duty-free store or an airport bar, thinking you have a few more minutes until your flight is set to go, know this: the plane’s doors might have already closed.

articles.headline: A Chance to Tackle Inequality
articles.snippet: While lawmakers are debating the question of how much government we can afford, they have ignored the broader question of how much government we need.
articles.abstract: While lawmakers are debating the question of how much government we can afford, they have ignored the broader question of how much government we need.
articles.lead_paragraph: To judge by the newfound bipartisan chumminess exhibited last week, it seems suddenly possible that the president and Republican leaders will reach a deal before the end of the year to cut spending, raise taxes and prevent the country from toppling over the fiscal cliff and back into recession.

articles.headline: H.P. Claim Highlights a Gray Area in Software Sales
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard contends that Autonomy, the British software firm it acquired for $10 billion last year, misclassified revenue, including sales of hardware with sales of software licenses.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard contends that Autonomy, the British software firm it acquired for $10 billion last year, misclassified revenue, including sales of hardware with sales of software licenses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard’s accusations of “serious accounting improprieties” at Autonomy are eerily reminiscent of accounting missteps uncovered over a decade ago at software firms like MicroStrategy, Computer Associates and Lernout & Hauspie.

articles.headline: Where Pilgrims Landed, Thanksgiving Is Kept at Table, Not Mall
articles.snippet: Some of the country’s retailers said they would move up sales to Thanksgiving Day, but stores in some New England states, adhering to those states’ “blue laws,” will be closed Thursday.
articles.abstract: Some of the country’s retailers said they would move up sales to Thanksgiving Day, but stores in some New England states, adhering to those states’ “blue laws,” will be closed Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH, Mass. — Here in the birthplace of Thanksgiving, where the Pilgrims first gave thanks in 1621 for their harvest and their survival, some residents are giving thanks this year for something else: the Colonial-era blue laws that prevent retailers from opening their doors on the fourth Thursday of November.

articles.headline: Israel and Hamas Agree to a Cease-Fire, After a U.S.-Egypt Push
articles.snippet: Under a truce announced by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and the Egyptian foreign minister, Israel and Hamas agreed to end all hostilities. But it was unclear how it would be enforced.
articles.abstract: Under a truce announced by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and the Egyptian foreign minister, Israel and Hamas agreed to end all hostilities. But it was unclear how it would be enforced.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Under intense Egyptian and American pressure, Israel and the Palestinian militant group Hamas halted eight days of bloody conflict on Wednesday, averting a full-scale Israeli ground invasion of the Gaza Strip without resolving the underlying disputes.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Jodi Rudoren
